stt. XX 1. Hereditas is universal succession, sometimes under a will, sometimes ab intestato: legatum is singular succession, under a will only, to a part, directly or indirectly, of the testator's property: ‘legatum est delibatio hereditatis, qua testator exeo, qnod universum heredis toret, alicui quid collatum velit’ Dig. 30. 116. pr. Historically, the idea of legacy is inseparable from that ol testamentum a legacy can be charged only on a testamentary heir, and only through the will itself, Tit. 23. 10 inl. : no legates is eutitled unless some one accepts under the testamentum: no one can be a legatae who has not testamenti factio passiva (note on Tit. 14. pr. supr.); the words in which a legacy is given must be formal, imperative, and in the Latin tongue (civilia verba); ‘legatum est, quod legis modo, id est imperative, testamento relinquitur: nam ea, quae precativo modo relinquuntur, fideicommissa vocantur' Ulpian, reg. 24 1.

§2 The four formulae, alluded to here, in which legacies could be given under the older law, are described at length in Gaius ii. 192-223, and Ulpian, reg. 24. 2-13.
